Research has shown that typical levels of UV light found in sunlight do not significantly deactivate the virus responsible for COVID-19, and the notion that sunlight or UV light exposure can eradicate the coronavirus is flawed [1]. While UV-C radiation can inactivate viruses under controlled laboratory conditions, natural sunlight lacks the necessary intensity and controlled environment to achieve such inactivation [1]. Furthermore, epidemiological data demonstrate that COVID-19 has proliferated in regions with intense UV exposure, such as equatorial areas, which further disproves the idea that UV light can prevent the spread of the virus [1]. Artificial UV devices marketed for COVID-19 prevention are also ineffective for widespread prevention or personal sanitization, and their misuse can pose serious health risks, including skin damage and an increased risk of cancer [1]. Experts and organizations such as the World Health Organization do not recommend using UV light as a preventive measure against COVID-19, instead emphasizing proven strategies like mask-wearing, handwashing, and vaccination, [0, 1]. In summary, reliance on UV light as a preventive measure against COVID-19 is not supported by scientific evidence and should not replace established, evidence-based practices, [0, 1].
